subject: Re: [junit] Passing parameters to methods
msgSnippet: ... Correction: you don t have to maintain state across methods. Because each test is in its instance, there is no possibility of having the state modified.
messageBody:
Cedric Beust wrote:
> Still, it's far from perfect since you have to create one field on your
> class per parameter, make sure this state is maintained across methods and
> then read this state in the method.

Correction: you don't have to maintain state across methods. Because
each test is in its instance, there is no possibility of having the
state modified.

> public class A extends TestCase {
> private String m_name;
> private String m_xmlFileName;
>
> public A(String name, String xmlFileName) {
> m_name = name;
> m_xmlFileName = xmlFileName;
> }
>
> public void testName() {
> // do something with m_name
> }
>
> public void testXmlFileName) {
> // do something with m_xmlFileName
> }
> }

Try again. Parameterized Test Cases in JUnit are best done with only
one type of test per class. Like so:

public class NameTest extends TestCase {
private String m_name;
private NameTest(String name) {
m_name = name;
super.setName("NameTest" - name); // give the test a meaningful
name for reports.
}
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite testSuite = new TestSuite();
testSuite.add(new NameTest("name");
// create instances for other types of names here. Maybe read them
from a file?
}

protected void runTest() {
// test the name.
}
}


public class ValidNameTest extends TestCase {
private String m_name;
private NameTest(String name) {
m_validName = name;
super.setName("ValidNameTest" - name); // give the test a
meaningful name for reports.
}
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite testSuite = new TestSuite();
testSuite.add(new ValidNameTest("validName");
// create instances for other types of names here. Maybe read them
from a file?
}

protected void runTest() {
// test the vallid name
}
}

The major advantage of this technique is that I can easily create
tests for lots of valid names. If I'm reading it from a file, the list
could be quite extensive _and_ you'll know which names passed the test
and which names didn't.

Out of curiousity: any easy way to do this in TestNG?
("Parameterising" a list or a file name doesn't count; you wouldn't
get the easy reporting of the bad values vs the good values).

Robert.
